meanings.definition: To supplement or add to something in order to make it last longer.
meanings.sent1: She tried to eke out her savings by cutting down on unnecessary expenses.
meanings.sent2: The farmer had to eke out his water supply during the drought.
meanings.sent3: He decided to eke out his shampoo by diluting it with water.
meanings.sent4: The candle flame flickered, struggling to eke out its last bit of wax.
meanings.sent5: The old car was trying to eke out a few more miles before breaking down.

meanings.definition: To make a living or support oneself by doing something in addition to one's primary occupation.
meanings.sent1: She had to eke by working part-time while studying in college.
meanings.sent2: The artist had to eke a living by selling paintings on weekends.
meanings.sent3: He tried to eke by as a musician while looking for a full-time job.
meanings.sent4: The writer had to eke a living out of freelance gigs before getting a book deal.
meanings.sent5: The actor had to eke by with odd jobs between acting roles.
